Award.AwardTitle: The Engineering Education Maker Identity Project

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research effort at Texas State University, a large Hispanic Serving Institution in San Marcos, Texas, advances the field of engineering education by exploring the creative and novel learning environment of Makerspaces in a university setting while benefiting current Engineering/Engineering Technology students as well as Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) Education students (future teachers). The research team will study issues relating to the effects of these novel learning environments on engineering learning and how these spaces may best leverage the real world experiences of students as pathways to engineering, including prior work on the ranch, farm, construction, home or military. Reaching over 900 students, University partners and faculty will carry out design and engineering activities that value students and their prior making skills, life experiences, and cultural funds of knowledge. The project will examine how design courses may be restructured to foster a positive and inclusive environment and enhance the success of students from underrepresented populations.

Makerspace experiences have the potential to be a valuable complement to structured classroom learning, but little is known about how and in what ways they are effective, and what characteristics of makerspaces optimize their effectiveness. The primary experimental work for this research aims to: 1) discover key concepts and principles that particularly enable a more diverse group of students to leverage creativity and innovation toward success in engineering careers; 2) discover specific learning models that involve both STEM university students and pre-service teachers in order to develop teamwork, self -efficacy, communication, and identity formation in the Maker environment; and 3) validate instruments to measure the impact of such programs on students self-efficacy, communication, and identity formation. Perspectives gained will facilitate the retention and persistence to graduation of participating students. The insights gained from this research will enable institutions across the nation to be able to restructure design-based education and engineering courses so as to enhance student success by incorporating makerspace-based design projects. The project employs a non-cost prohibitive and replicable approach as well as a model for scaling operation and research to a broad level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Engineering Education Maker Identity Project was a research effort that investigated the effect of makerspaces on student identity and learning. This project was led by a collaborative team of engineering education researchers from Texas State University?s departments of Engineering Technology and Curriculum & Instruction and the LBJ Institute for STEM Education & Research. The team organized, outfitted and directed a new small research university makerspace called  ?Bobcat Made?. This laboratory design and making space was opened at no cost to university students where they were trained in the safe use of digital, robotic and simple hand tools. The co-PI team mentored student volunteers who staffed daily open lab hours and provided technical training to university student users. Additionally, the team organized professional development workshops in active learning pedagogy/integrated STEM makerspace learning approaches and technical tool training for interested university faculty. As part of the research efforts, the co-PI team partnered with interested faculty members to implement maker-centered projects into their courses. An IRB approved research effort allowed the research team to collect survey and interview data from student and faculty study participants. 

This project resulted in makerspace and maker-centered projects being implemented in 24 courses during the 4 year project.  These courses served a variety of content areas, including, psychology, education majors (both pre- and in-service STEM teachers), and STEM (engineering, engineering technology, chemistry, and mathematics,).  Approximately 800 students were involved in these courses, thus experienced some aspect of the ?Maker-revised? curricular approach in their course.  Through examination of student makerspace use (for both personal creation/making and course-related creation/making) this project used pre-/post-survey methods to uncover key concepts and principles that might enable a more diverse group of students to leverage the university makerspace for their own creativity and innovation toward success in STEM and STEM education careers. From the data analyzed to date, the clear finding was that the community of learners that was formed by students happened due to their involvement in makerspace projects. This sense of belonging transferred to impact their perceptions of self-efficacy in becoming Makers. Self-efficacy is an important concept that can be paraphrased as a person?s belief in their own ability to complete a specific task.  For engineering students, these experiences also increased their engineering design self-efficacy. Self-efficacy has been shown to be linked to student retention in college.  Therefore, curriculum-based interventions that can trigger increased student self-efficacy are greatly desired for their potential to help with student retention.  Pre- and in-service STEM teachers were also targeted for this project in order to broaden the impact into the K-12 teacher preparation realm.  It was hypothesized that teachers who are more confident in understanding and applying the engineering design process will do a better job teaching K-12 students about engineering than teachers who lack understanding in this area. 

Noteworthy in the current data analysis is that the way the maker-centered project was presented to the class appears to mitigate the impact of these projects on students? engineering design self-efficacy changes.  To maximize positive impact of the project, discussion and use of the engineering design process are key elements to a successful maker-centered project. The research conducted in this study involved a fair representation of self-identified historically underrepresented students in STEM (women, Latinx, and African American students). Many revealed their valuable inherent experiences and skills that prepared them to be open to working with tools and creative media.  However, they benefitted when their instructors explicitly pointed out the connections of their funds of knowledge to important skillsets in STEM and STEM education careers.

More longitudinal efforts are needed that can follow both the STEM students who participated in these experiences and the future educators prepared in this approach, in order to measure long term impacts.
